title: What Font Please!
content:
Help me please check the P Y and N

[http://i260.photobucket.com/albums/ii18/pantshappy1/scan55.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/i260.photobucket.com/albums/ii18/pantshappy1/scan55.jpg "http://i260.photobucket.com/albums/ii18/pantshappy1/scan55.jpg")

 [‹ Carole King's "Tapestry" album typeface](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42059 "Go to previous forum topic") [The Magnificents album Banner FONT ID ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/www.typophile.com/node/42061 "Go to next forum topic")
author: markdayao

comments.content:
Hi Mark,

that looks like [Akzidenz-Grotesk](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Akzidenz%252BGrotesk) Extra Bold Condensed.  
F

I think Florian is right. In the future, a handy little cheat:

[http://www.myfonts.com/WhatTheFont/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/WhatTheFont/ "http://www.myfonts.com/WhatTheFont/")

It works surprisingly well.

Akzidenz-Grotesk is the same for most of the letters but on the upper case N and Y there is slight variation than what Akzidenz-Grotesk has (the sharp angles). I circled the part I am talking about. Thanks!

[http://s260.photobucket.com/albums/ii18/pantshappy1/?action=view&current...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/s260.photobucket.com/albums/ii18/pantshappy1/?action=view&current=scan56.jpg "http://s260.photobucket.com/albums/ii18/pantshappy1/?action=view&current=scan56.jpg")

not sure if i’m completely wrong but isn’t that  
done so it won’t fill in on the press, if the font is used  
in a small font size (?). Isnt that one of the reasons  
there are different versions for poster, text etc...

don’t know...

kinda similar is Helvetica [Inserat](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/helvetica-inserat/)

but without hi-res capability, it’s difficult to know what the ink traps look like.

“not sure if i’m completely wrong but isn’t that  
done so it won’t fill in on the press, if the font is used  
in a small font size (?”

Yes, Lead type often has those little notches cut in to control the typeface better optically on an letterpress. The ink tends to get pushed out ever-so-slightly. Later digital versions of many typefaces eliminated this.

Those notches usually are referred to as [ink traps](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007164922/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/ink%252Btraps), as Brian has pointed out. As printing still involves ink and paper (though the overall quality has improved), the ink traps still are around – also in digital typefaces.

ahh ink traps...thats what they are called in english...  
couldnt remember the word in german either...

had it at school, ages ago...
